awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Pteridological Collections Consortium: An integrative approach to pteridophyte diversity over the last 420 million years
awd_abstract_narration:
Ferns and their relatives ("pteridophytes") arose approximately 420 million years ago and were the dominant plant groups for hundreds of millions of years afterwards. Today the pteridophytes are outnumbered by the diversity and abundance of other plant groups, such as those that bear flowers, but they remain diverse (with around 12,000 species), ecologically important, and are found throughout the world. This Thematic Collections Network (TCN) brings together 9 core institutions whose goal is to make digital images and data on the distribution and biology of 1.6 million fossil and modern ferns and their relatives available to researchers. This effort includes 39 US Museums and Herbaria that will provide on-line access of collections data to researchers worldwide who will be able to address pressing questions about the evolution, distribution, and biology of land plants.  This project would train students and reach the public through teacher training opportunities, the development of curriculum and education boxes and through the production of informative science videos. 

The Pteridological Collections Consortium TCN is an interdisciplinary initiative that will database, image, and disseminate information on an unprecedented number of extant and fossil pteridophyte specimens. The combining of neo- and paleobotanical collections data will produce an online resource via a Symbiota framework to enable research on the distribution, ecology, genetics, and deep-time evolution of an important group of vascular plants. Pteridophytes are important because they 1) are relatively diverse and have extensive global distributions, 2) are associated with evolutionary innovations that shaped adaptations to terrestrial ecosystems, 3) they are sensitive to local environmental conditions and play important roles in modern communities, and 4) they have an excellent fossil record for addressing deep-time questions. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ferns, horsetails, and lycopods (clubmosses), are among the oldest plants on Earth.  They flourished long before dinosaurs roamed, and they are still found around the globe today.  By studying these plants we can learn about the structure of ancient and modern forests, the climate of continents millennia ago, and the genetic relationships between plants.  Herbaria (research museum collections devoted to plants) curate specimens from around the world and throughout time.  The funds provided by this NSF Grant enabled herbaria across the United States to catalog and make digital images of their fern and fossil plant collections.  For many collections it was the first time a comprehensive catalog was made.  By cataloging the ferns and fossils to an online portal, these plant specimens emerged from their cabinets and drawers into the daylight of a website accessible to students, researchers, citizen scientists and the public.  Each collection has its own strengths and focus. Together, they provide basic information for asking questions about what types of plants grew or grow where, about changes in ferns and fern allies through many climate changes, and about how ferns have interacted with other types of plants over the millennia.  Knowing which species of ferns, clubmosses and horsetails grow in our grasslands and forests today and documenting their locations with pressed, dried herbarium specimens inform scientists studying plant distributions and land managers making decisions on how to best preserve or restore ecosystems.

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Herbarium (NCU) curates both extant (living today) and fossil plants. Some of the fossils are plants which grow today or have close relatives which are extant.  However, some of these fossils are of plants whose entire lineage is extinct.  NCU’s fossil collection is strongest in plants from the Devonian (410-380 million years ago), when plants were making the evolutionary journey from being strictly aquatic to living on solid land.  There are few places in the world where fossils of this age can be found.  Dr. Patricia Gensel’s main fossil study sites are in provinces of New Brunswick and Quebec, Canada.  In addition, NCU curates fossil relatives of ferns and lycopods from younger rocks of the Carboniferous (325 million years ago) and Triassic (250-200 million years ago) in North Carolina.  NCU’s collection of extant (living today) ferns, horsetails and clubmosses is world-wide in scope with a focus on the botanical biodiversity hotspot of the Southeastern United States. 

Arizona State University Herbarium (ASU) curates both extant and fossil plants. ASU’s fossil collection spans many geologic periods, but is particularly strong in plants from the Carboniferous (325 million years ago).  Carboniferous period plants grew in swamps and contributed biomass that forms coal seams around the world today.  ASU’s collection of extant ferns, horsetails and lycopods is worldwide in scope but with strong representation of those growing in the American Southwest, Mexico, and Central America. 

Duke University Herbarium (DUKE) curates extant plants from around the world.  The DUKE fern collection is particularly strong in plants from Central America as they have been a long-time participant in the Organization for Tropical Studies. 

The Garrett Herbarium, Natural History Museum of Utah (UT) has extant ferns, clubmosses and horsetails from around the globe, but their collection is particularly focused on those found in Utah.

The West Virginia University Herbarium (WVA) curates extant ferns, clubmosses and horsetails from around the world, but their collection is particularly focused on documenting the flora of West Virginia.  WVA curates about 500 specimens of ferns from Japan, many collected by Dr. Tomitaro Makino (1862-1957), the “Father of Japanese Botany”.

Between these five herbaria, examples of over 65,700 extant ferns, horsetails and clubmosses from around the globe were cataloged and digitally imaged.  In addition, about 2,600 fossil plants from many different periods including the Devonian, the Carboniferous, and the Triassic, have been cataloged and photographed.
